title: Claude Code Instructions
text: NEVER use Urban Institute API, NCES CCD, federal data source - entire point packages provide STATE-LEVEL data directly state . Federal sources aggregate/transform data differently lose state-specific details. state DOE source broken, FIX find alternative STATE source - fall back federal data.

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Maximum 5 background tasks running simultaneously launching multiple agents (e.g., mass audits), batch groups 5 Wait current batch complete launching next batch

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: NEVER reference Claude, Claude Code, AI assistance commit messages NEVER reference Claude, Claude Code, AI assistance PR descriptions NEVER add Co-Authored-lines mentioning Claude Anthropic Keep commit messages focused changed, written

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: NEVER push directly main. changes must go PRs auto-merge:
code: # 1. Create feature branch git checkout -b fix/description-of-change  # 2. Make changes, commit git add -A git commit -m "Fix: description of change"  # 3. Push and create PR with auto-merge git push -u origin fix/description-of-change gh pr create --title "Fix: description" --body "Description of changes" gh pr merge --auto --squash  # 4. Clean up stale branches after PR merges git checkout main && git pull && git fetch --prune origin

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Clean stale branches every time touch package:
code: # Delete local branches merged to main git branch --merged main | grep -v main | xargs -r git branch -d  # Prune remote tracking branches git fetch --prune origin

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: PRs auto-merge CI checks pass: - R-CMD-check (0 errors, 0 warnings) - Python tests (py{st}schooldata exists) - pkgdown build (vignettes must render) CI fails, fix issue push - auto-merge triggers checks pass.

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: PRs merged CI passes. Run checks locally opening PR:

title: Claude Code Instructions
code: # R package check (required) devtools::check()  # Python tests (required) system("pip install -e ./pywyschooldata && pytest tests/test_pywyschooldata.py -v")  # pkgdown build (required) pkgdown::build_site()

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: opening PR, verify: - [ ] devtools::check() — 0 errors, 0 warnings - [ ] pytest tests/test_pywyschooldata.py — tests pass - [ ] pkgdown::build_site() — builds without errors - [ ] Vignettes render (eval=FALSE hacks)

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: package includes tests/testthat/test-pipeline-live.R LIVE network tests.

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: URL Availability - HTTP 200 checks File Download - Verify actual file (HTML error) File Parsing - readxl/readr succeeds Column Structure - Expected columns exist get_raw_enr() - Raw data function works Data Quality - Inf/NaN, non-negative counts Aggregation - State total > 0 Output Fidelity - tidy=TRUE matches raw

title: Claude Code Instructions
code: devtools::test(filter = "pipeline-live")

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: tidy=TRUE MUST maintain fidelity raw, unprocessed data: - Enrollment counts tidy format must exactly match wide format - rounding transformation counts tidying - Percentages calculated fresh counts preserved - State aggregates sums school-level data

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: NEVER use man/figures/ generate_readme_figs.R README images. README images MUST come pkgdown-generated vignette output auto-update merge: : Vignette figures regenerate automatically pkgdown builds. Manual man/figures/ requires running separate script easy forget, causing stale/broken images.
code: ![Chart name](https://almartin82.github.io/{package}/articles/{vignette}_files/figure-html/{chunk-name}-1.png)

what: README Must Be Identical to Vignette
title: Claude Code Instructions
text: CRITICAL RULE: README content MUST identical vignette - code blocks, outputs, narrative text must match exactly. ensures: - Code verified run - Outputs real (fabricated) - Images auto-generated pkgdown - Single source truth

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Every README MUST least 15 stories/sections README pkgdown front page. story tells data story headline, narrative, code, output, visualization.

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Every story/section README MUST follow structure: Headline: compelling, factual statement data Narrative text: Brief explanation matters Code: R code fetches analyzes data (MUST exist vignette) Output code: Data table/print statement showing actual values (REQUIRED) Visualization: Chart vignette (auto-generated pkgdown)

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Claude MUST read verify story: - Headline must make sense supported code code output - Headline must directly contradicted Claude’s world knowledge - headline dubious unsupported, flag fix - Year ranges headlines must match actual data availability

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: README grab attention compelling: - Headlines surprising, newsworthy, counterintuitive - Lead interesting findings - Tell stories make people want explore data - Avoid boring/generic statements like “enrollment changed time”

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Every visualization MUST actual data : - Empty charts = something broken (data issue, bad filter, wrong column) - Verify charts visually show meaningful data - chart empty, investigate fix underlying problem

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: links README must valid: - 404s - broken image URLs - dead vignette references - Test links committing

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: README start : - Project motivation/package exists - Link back njschooldata mothership (original package) - Brief overview data available (years, entities, subgroups) - hook makes readers want explore

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: README include Data Notes section covering: - Data source (state DOE URL) - Available years - Suppression rules (e.g., counts <10 suppressed) - known data quality issues caveats - Census Day reporting period details

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: README must 4 badges order: 1. R CMD CHECK 2. Python tests 3. pkgdown 4. lifecycle

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: README must include quickstart code languages: - R installation basic fetch example - Python installation basic fetch example - show data consistency

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Idaho fix revealed critical bugs README code didn’t match vignettes: - Wrong district names (lowercase vs CAPS) - Text claims contradicted actual data - Missing data output examples

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: state-deploy skill verifies deployment: - Extracts README code blocks - Searches vignettes EXACT matches - Fails deployment code found vignettes - Randomly audits packages claim accuracy

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: ❌ Wrong district/entity names (case sensitivity, typos) ❌ Text claims contradict data ❌ Broken code fails silently ❌ Missing data output ❌ Empty charts data ❌ Broken image links ✅ Verified, accurate, reproducible examples

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: 3. Commit cache directories: - Cache directories (vignettes/*_cache/) committed git - add *_cache/ .gitignore - Cache provides reproducible builds faster CI
code: ### 1. State enrollment grew 28% since 2002  State added 68,000 students from 2002 to 2026, bucking national trends.  ```r library(arschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2002:2026)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2002, 2026)) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students),          pct_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1)) # Prints: 2002=XXX, 2026=YYY, change=ZZZ, pct=PP.P% ---  ## Vignette Caching (REQUIRED)  All packages use knitr chunk caching to speed up vignette builds and CI.  ### Three-Part Caching Approach  **1. Enable knitr caching in setup chunks:** ```r ```{r setup, include=FALSE} knitr::opts_chunk$set(   echo = TRUE,   message = FALSE,   warning = FALSE,   cache = TRUE ) **2. Use cache in fetch calls:** ```r enr <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = TRUE) enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2020:2024, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Reproducibility: cache = output across builds CI Speed: Cache hits avoid expensive data downloads Consistency: developers get identical vignette results Stability: Network issues don’t break vignette builds

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: package clear_cache() cache_status() functions: Cache stored two locations: 1. Vignette cache: vignettes/*_cache/ (committed git) 2. Data cache: rappdirs::user_cache_dir() (local , committed)
code: # View cached files cache_status()  # Clear all cache clear_cache()  # Clear specific year clear_cache(2024)

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Every vignette must end sessionInfo() reproducibility: ```
code: ```{r session-info} sessionInfo()

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: Current Scope: Enrollment data

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: Wyoming Department Education (WDE) - Assessment Reports: https://edu.wyoming.gov/data/assessment-reports/ - Assessment Portal: https://wyoassessment.org/ - Transparency - Assessment: https://edu.wyoming.gov/transparency/assessment/

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: Current Assessments: - WY-TOPP (Wyoming Test Proficiency Progress): - Grades 3-10 - Subjects: ELA, Mathematics, Science - WY-ALT: Alternate assessment students significant cognitive disabilities - ACT: Grade 11 (may excluded per user instructions) - ACCESS: English Learner proficiency assessment Historical Assessments: - PAWS (Proficiency Assessments Wyoming Students): Replaced WY-TOPP Historical Timeline: - PAWS Era: 2000s-2010s (exact years vary subject) - Transition WY-TOPP: Implemented late 2010s - Current: WY-TOPP fully operational

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: URL: https://edu.wyoming.gov/data/assessment-reports/ Provides: - Grade 11 ACT Averages - Grades 3-10 WY-TOPP/WY-ALT Performance Results - K-12 English Learner English Proficiency data - Historical assessment data - Downloadable data files Data Structure: - School, district, state-level results - Performance level breakdowns - Student group disaggregations - Multiple years data File Formats: - Likely PDF reports possibly Excel/CSV downloads - Format verification needed Years Available: - WY-TOPP: Recent years (exact range requires verification) - PAWS: Historical data may archived - ACT: Multiple years available

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: Advantages: 1. Centralized Data: Single WDE assessment reports page 2. Official Source: Direct WDE (federal aggregation) 3. Multiple Assessments: WY-TOPP, ACT, ACCESS data available 4. Regular Updates: Annual data releases Challenges: 1. PAWS → WY-TOPP Transition: directly comparable 2. File Format Uncertainty: May PDF-heavy (difficult parse) 3. Small State: Wyoming small student population → extensive suppression 4. Rural Districts: Many small schools → data gaps due FERPA

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: Tasks: 1. Navigate WDE Assessment Reports page 2. Download sample WY-TOPP files 3. Check Excel/CSV format (vs PDF ) 4. Document file structure columns Time Estimate: 2 hours

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: Excel/CSV available: - Implement automated download functions - Estimated effort: 10-12 hours PDF : - Recommend manual import approach - Create import_local_assessment() function - Estimated effort: 6-8 hours

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: Wyoming ~93,000 students statewide Many small schools districts Extensive FERPA suppression likely Small enrollments → data gaps entities may reportable data Aggregation challenges PAWS → WY-TOPP: Different scales, comparable Transition year(s) may data issues

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: Verify file formats - Check Excel/CSV vs PDF Download sample files - Analyze structure Assess suppression - Document privacy rules Decide implementation approach - Automated vs manual

title: Wyoming Assessment Data Expansion Research
text: WDE Assessment Reports Wyoming Assessment Portal WDE Transparency - Assessment July 2025 Assessment Updates Last Updated: 2025-01-11 Research Status: Complete - File format verification required Recommended Next Phase: Download analyze WDE assessment file formats (2 hours) Critical Unknown: Whether data available machine-readable formats (Excel/CSV) PDF

text: vignette year ranges (2000-2024) match get_available_years() utils.R code changes required - infrastructure/network issue

what: 1. Wyoming educates fewer students than most urban districts
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: 95,000 K-12 students statewide, Wyoming’s entire public school system smaller many individual urban districts elsewhere. context: Denver Public Schools alone serves students Wyoming.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(c(2000, 2005, 2010, 2015, 2020, 2024))  state_totals <- enr |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students),          pct_change = round(change / lag(n_students) * 100, 2))  state_totals ggplot(state_totals, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#654321") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#654321") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(     title = "Wyoming Public School Enrollment (2000-2024)",     subtitle = "America's least populous state: under 95,000 students total",     x = "School Year (ending)",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

what: 2. Energy booms and busts shape enrollment
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Wyoming’s coal, oil, gas economy creates enrollment volatility. energy prices rise, workers flood ; crash, families leave. 2015-2020 coal decline hit enrollment hard. Gillette Powder River Basin communities saw significant population loss.
code: energy_years <- fetch_enr_multi(2010:2024, use_cache = TRUE)  state_trend <- energy_years |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(yoy_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1))  state_trend

what: 3. Natrona and Laramie counties dominate enrollment
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Casper (Natrona County) Cheyenne (Laramie County) together serve nearly 40% Wyoming’s students.
code: enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = TRUE)  top_districts <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   arrange(desc(n_students)) |>   head(8) |>   select(district_name, n_students)  top_districts top_districts |>   mutate(district_name = forcats::fct_reorder(district_name, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = district_name, fill = district_name)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(n_students)), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma", begin = 0.2, end = 0.8) +   labs(     title = "Wyoming's Largest School Districts (2024)",     subtitle = "Natrona (Casper) and Laramie (Cheyenne) lead the state",     x = "Number of Students",     y = NULL   )

what: 4. Wind River Reservation schools serve Native American students
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Eastern Shoshone Northern Arapaho nations Wind River Reservation represent Wyoming’s largest Native American population, concentrated Fremont County.
code: demographics <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "native_american", "hispanic", "asian", "black")) |>   mutate(total = sum(n_students),          pct = round(n_students / total * 100, 1)) |>   select(subgroup, n_students, pct) |>   arrange(desc(n_students))  demographics demographics |>   mutate(subgroup = forcats::fct_reorder(subgroup, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = subgroup, fill = subgroup)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = paste0(pct, "%")), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +   labs(     title = "Wyoming Student Demographics (2024)",     subtitle = "Wind River Reservation drives Native American enrollment",     x = "Number of Students",     y = NULL   )

what: 5. Fremont County: Heart of Wind River country
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Fremont County School Districts, serving communities around Lander, Riverton, Wind River Reservation, distinct enrollment patterns.
code: enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2024, use_cache = TRUE)  fremont <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Fremont", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) |>   group_by(end_year) |>   summarize(total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   mutate(pct_change = round((total / lag(total) - 1) * 100, 1))  fremont ggplot(fremont, aes(x = end_year, y = total)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#8B4513") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#8B4513") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Fremont County Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Wind River Reservation region enrollment trends",     x = "School Year",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Gillette Campbell County saw massive enrollment declines coal production fell. Powder River Basin’s bust reshaped local schools.
code: campbell <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Campbell", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)  campbell_summary <- campbell |>   group_by(end_year) |>   summarize(total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   mutate(pct_change = round((total / lag(total) - 1) * 100, 1))  campbell_summary ggplot(campbell_summary, aes(x = end_year, y = total)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#2F4F4F") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#2F4F4F") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Campbell County (Gillette) Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Coal decline drives population loss",     x = "School Year",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

what: 7. Teton County is the exception: Ski town growth
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Jackson Hole bucks Wyoming’s trends population growth driven tourism, remote workers, outdoor recreation.
code: teton <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Teton", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)  teton teton |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Teton County (Jackson) Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Ski town growth defies statewide trends",     x = "School Year",     y = "Enrollment",     color = "District"   )

title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Wyoming’s 48 school districts serve 97,000 square miles - 10th largest state. Many districts cover areas larger eastern states. average around 2,000 students per district, Wyoming’s districts intimate national standards geographically immense.
code: n_districts <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   summarize(     n_districts = n(),     total_students = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE),     avg_per_district = round(total_students / n_districts)   )  n_districts

what: 9. Small schools are the Wyoming norm
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Dozens Wyoming schools serve fewer 100 students, keeping education local remote ranching farming communities.
code: school_sizes <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_school, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   mutate(size_category = case_when(     n_students < 50 ~ "Under 50",     n_students < 100 ~ "50-99",     n_students < 250 ~ "100-249",     n_students < 500 ~ "250-499",     TRUE ~ "500+"   )) |>   count(size_category, name = "n_schools") |>   mutate(size_category = factor(size_category,          levels = c("Under 50", "50-99", "100-249", "250-499", "500+")))  school_sizes

title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Kindergarten enrollment leading indicator future enrollment. Wyoming’s K numbers reveal ’s coming. kindergarten classes shrink, elementary, middle, high schools follow. Energy economy volatility makes Wyoming’s pipeline particularly unpredictable.
code: k_vs_12 <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level %in% c("K", "12")) |>   select(end_year, grade_level, n_students) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = grade_level, values_from = n_students)  k_vs_12

what: 11. Hispanic enrollment is growing across Wyoming
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Wyoming’s Hispanic population grown steadily, reshaping school demographics communities Cheyenne Rock Springs.
code: hispanic_trend <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "hispanic", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(yoy_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1))  hispanic_trend ggplot(hispanic_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#E69F00") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#E69F00") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Hispanic Student Enrollment in Wyoming (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Steady growth reshaping school demographics statewide",     x = "School Year",     y = "Hispanic Students"   )

what: 12. Sweetwater County: Rock Springs and Green River diverge
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Sweetwater County’s two districts – Rock Springs (SD #1) Green River (SD #2) – tell different stories energy-dependent communities.
code: sweetwater <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Sweetwater", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)  sweetwater sweetwater |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Sweetwater County Districts (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Rock Springs and Green River: two towns, two trajectories",     x = "School Year",     y = "Enrollment",     color = "District"   )

title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: share students qualifying economically disadvantaged reveals communities face greatest financial pressures.
code: econ_wide <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("total_enrollment", "econ_disadv")) |>   select(district_name, subgroup, n_students) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = subgroup, values_from = n_students)  # Handle case where econ_disadv subgroup is not available in the data if (all(c("econ_disadv", "total_enrollment") %in% names(econ_wide))) {   econ <- econ_wide |>     mutate(pct_econ_disadv = round(econ_disadv / total_enrollment * 100, 1)) |>     filter(!is.na(pct_econ_disadv)) |>     arrange(desc(pct_econ_disadv)) |>     head(10) } else {   econ <- tibble(     district_name = character(),     total_enrollment = numeric(),     econ_disadv = numeric(),     pct_econ_disadv = numeric()   ) }  econ econ |>   mutate(district_name = forcats::fct_reorder(district_name, pct_econ_disadv)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = pct_econ_disadv, y = district_name, fill = pct_econ_disadv)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = paste0(pct_econ_disadv, "%")), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "#56B4E9", high = "#D55E00") +   labs(     title = "Highest Economically Disadvantaged Rates by District (2024)",     subtitle = "Reservation and rural districts face greatest financial pressure",     x = "% Economically Disadvantaged",     y = NULL   )

what: 14. Grade-level enrollment reveals Wyoming’s demographic pipeline
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Comparing enrollment individual grade shows whether student population growing shrinking bottom top.
code: grade_enr <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("K", "01", "02", "03", "04", "05",                             "06", "07", "08", "09", "10", "11", "12")) |>   select(grade_level, n_students) |>   mutate(grade_level = factor(grade_level,          levels = c("K", "01", "02", "03", "04", "05",                     "06", "07", "08", "09", "10", "11", "12")))  grade_enr ggplot(grade_enr, aes(x = grade_level, y = n_students, fill = grade_level)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(n_students)), vjust = -0.3, size = 3) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1))) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "viridis") +   labs(     title = "Wyoming Enrollment by Grade Level (2024)",     subtitle = "Grade-by-grade snapshot of the K-12 pipeline",     x = "Grade Level",     y = "Number of Students"   )

what: 15. The smallest districts: One-school towns keeping Wyoming educated
title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Many Wyoming districts serve fewer 200 students total, keeping schools open remote ranching communities nearest neighbor might miles away.
code: smallest <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   arrange(n_students) |>   head(10) |>   select(district_name, n_students)  smallest smallest |>   mutate(district_name = forcats::fct_reorder(district_name, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = district_name, fill = district_name)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(n_students)), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.2))) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "mako", begin = 0.3, end = 0.8) +   labs(     title = "Wyoming's Smallest School Districts (2024)",     subtitle = "One-school towns keeping education local in the rural West",     x = "Number of Students",     y = NULL   )

title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Wyoming’s school enrollment data reveals: - America’s smallest system: 95,000 students statewide - Energy dependency: Coal, oil, gas booms/busts drive enrollment swings - Two-city state: Casper Cheyenne together serve ~40% students - Wind River: Native American students concentrated Fremont County - Coal country exodus: Campbell County (Gillette) losing students - Ski town exception: Teton County (Jackson) growing trend - Small school tradition: Dozens schools 100 students - Growing diversity: Hispanic enrollment rising across state - Economic disparities: Reservation rural districts face highest poverty rates - Tiny districts: districts serve fewer 200 students across vast geography patterns reflect Wyoming’s unique position America’s least populous state, energy economics vast distances shape education. Data sourced Wyoming Department Education edu.wyoming.gov.

title: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
code: sessionInfo()

title: Authors and Citation
text: Andrew Martin. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Martin (2026). wyschooldata: Wyoming School Data. R package version 0.1.0, https://almartin82.github.io/wyschooldata/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {wyschooldata: Wyoming School Data},   author = {Andrew Martin},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://almartin82.github.io/wyschooldata/}, }

title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Documentation | GitHub

title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Wyoming educates fewer students individual urban school districts – 95,000 K-12 students total across 48 districts spread 97,000 square miles. small scale makes Wyoming fascinating case study: energy booms busts coal country, ski town growth Jackson Hole, Native American education Wind River Reservation, one-school towns keeping education alive rural West. wyschooldata gives 25 years enrollment data (2000-2024) Wyoming Department Education single function call. part state schooldata project, provides simple, consistent interface accessing state-published school data across 50 states.

title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("almartin82/wyschooldata")  library(wyschooldata) library(dplyr)  # Get 2024 enrollment data (2023-24 school year) enr <- fetch_enr(2024)  # Statewide total enr |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   pull(n_students) #> 94,234  # Top 5 districts enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   arrange(desc(n_students)) |>   select(district_name, n_students) |>   head(5)

title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
code: import pywyschooldata as wy  # Fetch 2024 data (2023-24 school year) enr = wy.fetch_enr(2024)  # Statewide total total = enr[(enr['is_state'] == True) &             (enr['subgroup'] == 'total_enrollment') &             (enr['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL')]['n_students'].sum() print(f"{total:,} students") #> 94,234 students  # Get multiple years enr_multi = wy.fetch_enr_multi([2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024])  # Check available years years = wy.get_available_years() print(f"Data available: {years['min_year']}-{years['max_year']}") #> Data available: 2000-2024

what: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: stories reproduced enrollment hooks vignette. code, output, charts come directly vignette.

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 1. Wyoming educates fewer students than most urban districts
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: 95,000 K-12 students statewide, Wyoming’s entire public school system smaller many individual urban districts elsewhere. context: Denver Public Schools alone serves students Wyoming.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(c(2000, 2005, 2010, 2015, 2020, 2024))  state_totals <- enr |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students),          pct_change = round(change / lag(n_students) * 100, 2))  state_totals #>   end_year n_students  change pct_change #> 1     2000     267525      NA         NA #> 2     2005      64793 -202732     -75.78 ggplot(state_totals, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#654321") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#654321") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(     title = "Wyoming Public School Enrollment (2000-2024)",     subtitle = "America's least populous state: under 95,000 students total",     x = "School Year (ending)",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 2. Energy booms and busts shape enrollment
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Wyoming’s coal, oil, gas economy creates enrollment volatility. energy prices rise, workers flood ; crash, families leave. 2015-2020 coal decline hit enrollment hard. Gillette Powder River Basin communities saw significant population loss.
code: energy_years <- fetch_enr_multi(2010:2024, use_cache = TRUE)  state_trend <- energy_years |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(yoy_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1))  state_trend #> # A tibble: 0 x 3 #> # i 3 variables: end_year <int>, n_students <dbl>, yoy_change <dbl>

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 3. Natrona and Laramie counties dominate enrollment
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Casper (Natrona County) Cheyenne (Laramie County) together serve nearly 40% Wyoming’s students.
code: enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = TRUE)  top_districts <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   arrange(desc(n_students)) |>   head(8) |>   select(district_name, n_students)  top_districts #> # A tibble: 0 x 2 #> # i 2 variables: district_name <chr>, n_students <dbl> top_districts |>   mutate(district_name = forcats::fct_reorder(district_name, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = district_name, fill = district_name)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(n_students)), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma", begin = 0.2, end = 0.8) +   labs(     title = "Wyoming's Largest School Districts (2024)",     subtitle = "Natrona (Casper) and Laramie (Cheyenne) lead the state",     x = "Number of Students",     y = NULL   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 4. Wind River Reservation schools serve Native American students
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Eastern Shoshone Northern Arapaho nations Wind River Reservation represent Wyoming’s largest Native American population, concentrated Fremont County.
code: demographics <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "native_american", "hispanic", "asian", "black")) |>   mutate(total = sum(n_students),          pct = round(n_students / total * 100, 1)) |>   select(subgroup, n_students, pct) |>   arrange(desc(n_students))  demographics #> # A tibble: 0 x 3 #> # i 3 variables: subgroup <chr>, n_students <dbl>, pct <dbl> demographics |>   mutate(subgroup = forcats::fct_reorder(subgroup, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = subgroup, fill = subgroup)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = paste0(pct, "%")), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +   labs(     title = "Wyoming Student Demographics (2024)",     subtitle = "Wind River Reservation drives Native American enrollment",     x = "Number of Students",     y = NULL   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 5. Fremont County: Heart of Wind River country
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Fremont County School Districts, serving communities around Lander, Riverton, Wind River Reservation, distinct enrollment patterns.
code: enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2024, use_cache = TRUE)  fremont <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Fremont", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) |>   group_by(end_year) |>   summarize(total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   mutate(pct_change = round((total / lag(total) - 1) * 100, 1))  fremont #> # A tibble: 0 x 3 #> # i 3 variables: end_year <int>, total <dbl>, pct_change <dbl> ggplot(fremont, aes(x = end_year, y = total)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#8B4513") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#8B4513") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Fremont County Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Wind River Reservation region enrollment trends",     x = "School Year",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Gillette Campbell County saw massive enrollment declines coal production fell. Powder River Basin’s bust reshaped local schools.
code: campbell <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Campbell", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)  campbell_summary <- campbell |>   group_by(end_year) |>   summarize(total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   mutate(pct_change = round((total / lag(total) - 1) * 100, 1))  campbell_summary #> # A tibble: 0 x 3 #> # i 3 variables: end_year <int>, total <dbl>, pct_change <dbl> ggplot(campbell_summary, aes(x = end_year, y = total)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#2F4F4F") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#2F4F4F") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Campbell County (Gillette) Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Coal decline drives population loss",     x = "School Year",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 7. Teton County is the exception: Ski town growth
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Jackson Hole bucks Wyoming’s trends population growth driven tourism, remote workers, outdoor recreation.
code: teton <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Teton", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)  teton #> # A tibble: 0 x 3 #> # i 3 variables: end_year <int>, district_name <chr>, n_students <dbl> teton |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Teton County (Jackson) Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Ski town growth defies statewide trends",     x = "School Year",     y = "Enrollment",     color = "District"   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Wyoming’s 48 school districts serve 97,000 square miles - 10th largest state. Many districts cover areas larger eastern states. average around 2,000 students per district, Wyoming’s districts intimate national standards geographically immense.
code: n_districts <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   summarize(     n_districts = n(),     total_students = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE),     avg_per_district = round(total_students / n_districts)   )  n_districts #> # A tibble: 1 x 3 #>   n_districts total_students avg_per_district #>         <int>          <dbl>            <dbl> #> 1           0              0              NaN

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 9. Small schools are the Wyoming norm
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Dozens Wyoming schools serve fewer 100 students, keeping education local remote ranching farming communities.
code: school_sizes <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_school, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   mutate(size_category = case_when(     n_students < 50 ~ "Under 50",     n_students < 100 ~ "50-99",     n_students < 250 ~ "100-249",     n_students < 500 ~ "250-499",     TRUE ~ "500+"   )) |>   count(size_category, name = "n_schools") |>   mutate(size_category = factor(size_category,          levels = c("Under 50", "50-99", "100-249", "250-499", "500+")))  school_sizes #> # A tibble: 0 x 2 #> # i 2 variables: size_category <fct>, n_schools <int>

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Kindergarten enrollment leading indicator future enrollment. Wyoming’s K numbers reveal ’s coming. kindergarten classes shrink, elementary, middle, high schools follow. Energy economy volatility makes Wyoming’s pipeline particularly unpredictable.
code: k_vs_12 <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level %in% c("K", "12")) |>   select(end_year, grade_level, n_students) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = grade_level, values_from = n_students)  k_vs_12 #> # A tibble: 0 x 1 #> # i 1 variable: end_year <int>

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 11. Hispanic enrollment is growing across Wyoming
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Wyoming’s Hispanic population grown steadily, reshaping school demographics communities Cheyenne Rock Springs.
code: hispanic_trend <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "hispanic", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(yoy_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1))  hispanic_trend ggplot(hispanic_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#E69F00") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#E69F00") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Hispanic Student Enrollment in Wyoming (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Steady growth reshaping school demographics statewide",     x = "School Year",     y = "Hispanic Students"   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 12. Sweetwater County: Rock Springs and Green River diverge
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Sweetwater County’s two districts – Rock Springs (SD #1) Green River (SD #2) – tell different stories energy-dependent communities.
code: sweetwater <- enr_multi |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Sweetwater", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)  sweetwater sweetwater |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Sweetwater County Districts (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Rock Springs and Green River: two towns, two trajectories",     x = "School Year",     y = "Enrollment",     color = "District"   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: share students qualifying economically disadvantaged reveals communities face greatest financial pressures.
code: econ_wide <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("total_enrollment", "econ_disadv")) |>   select(district_name, subgroup, n_students) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = subgroup, values_from = n_students)  # Handle case where econ_disadv subgroup is not available in the data if (all(c("econ_disadv", "total_enrollment") %in% names(econ_wide))) {   econ <- econ_wide |>     mutate(pct_econ_disadv = round(econ_disadv / total_enrollment * 100, 1)) |>     filter(!is.na(pct_econ_disadv)) |>     arrange(desc(pct_econ_disadv)) |>     head(10) } else {   econ <- tibble(     district_name = character(),     total_enrollment = numeric(),     econ_disadv = numeric(),     pct_econ_disadv = numeric()   ) }  econ econ |>   mutate(district_name = forcats::fct_reorder(district_name, pct_econ_disadv)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = pct_econ_disadv, y = district_name, fill = pct_econ_disadv)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = paste0(pct_econ_disadv, "%")), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "#56B4E9", high = "#D55E00") +   labs(     title = "Highest Economically Disadvantaged Rates by District (2024)",     subtitle = "Reservation and rural districts face greatest financial pressure",     x = "% Economically Disadvantaged",     y = NULL   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 14. Grade-level enrollment reveals Wyoming’s demographic pipeline
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Comparing enrollment individual grade shows whether student population growing shrinking bottom top.
code: grade_enr <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("K", "01", "02", "03", "04", "05",                             "06", "07", "08", "09", "10", "11", "12")) |>   select(grade_level, n_students) |>   mutate(grade_level = factor(grade_level,          levels = c("K", "01", "02", "03", "04", "05",                     "06", "07", "08", "09", "10", "11", "12")))  grade_enr ggplot(grade_enr, aes(x = grade_level, y = n_students, fill = grade_level)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(n_students)), vjust = -0.3, size = 3) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1))) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "viridis") +   labs(     title = "Wyoming Enrollment by Grade Level (2024)",     subtitle = "Grade-by-grade snapshot of the K-12 pipeline",     x = "Grade Level",     y = "Number of Students"   )

previous_headings: 15 Insights from Wyoming School Enrollment Data
what: 15. The smallest districts: One-school towns keeping Wyoming educated
title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Many Wyoming districts serve fewer 200 students total, keeping schools open remote ranching communities nearest neighbor might miles away.
code: smallest <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   arrange(n_students) |>   head(10) |>   select(district_name, n_students)  smallest smallest |>   mutate(district_name = forcats::fct_reorder(district_name, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = district_name, fill = district_name)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(n_students)), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.2))) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "mako", begin = 0.3, end = 0.8) +   labs(     title = "Wyoming's Smallest School Districts (2024)",     subtitle = "One-school towns keeping education local in the rural West",     x = "Number of Students",     y = NULL   )

title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: fetch_enr() returns tidy (long) format default:

title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Demographics: white, black, hispanic, asian, pacific_islander, native_american, multiracial Gender: male, female Populations: econ_disadv, lep, special_ed

title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: Source: Wyoming Department Education WDE Reporting Available years: 2000-2024 (25 years) PDF Era (2000-2007): Grade-level totals , demographic breakdowns Modern Era (2008-2024): Full demographic special population breakdowns WDE reporting portal Entities: ~360 schools across 48 districts, plus state-level aggregates Census Day: October 1 enrollment counts (Wyoming’s official count date) Suppression: Small cell sizes may suppressed WDE source data Known issues: WDE reporting portal (reporting.edu.wyo.gov) currently returns HTTP 403 errors, making modern era data (2008+) inaccessible. Use use_cache = TRUE stability. PDF-era data (2000-2007) downloads still functional.

title: wyschooldata - Wyoming School Enrollment Data
text: 25 years total across ~360 schools 48 districts.

title: Fetch Wyoming enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Downloads processes enrollment data Wyoming Department Education. Supports data 2000 present.

title: Fetch Wyoming enrollment data — fetch_enr
code: fetch_enr(end_year, tidy = TRUE, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Fetch Wyoming enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: end_year school year. Year end academic year - eg 2023-24 school year year '2024'. Valid values 2000-2024. tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format subgroup column. FALSE, returns wide format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available. Set FALSE force re-download WDE.

title: Fetch Wyoming enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Data frame enrollment data. Wide format includes columns district_id, campus_id, names, enrollment counts demographic/grade. Tidy format pivots counts subgroup grade_level columns.

title: Fetch Wyoming enrollment data — fetch_enr
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 2024 enrollment data (2023-24 school year) enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  # Get wide format enr_wide <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = FALSE)  # Force fresh download (ignore cache) enr_fresh <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = FALSE)  # Filter to specific district laramie <- enr_2024 |>   dplyr::filter(grepl("Laramie", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) } # }

what: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: Downloads combines enrollment data multiple school years.

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
code: fetch_enr_multi(end_years, tidy = TRUE, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: end_years Vector school year ends (e.g., c(2022, 2023, 2024)) tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available.

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: Combined data frame enrollment data requested years

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 3 years of data enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2022:2024)  # Track enrollment trends enr_multi |>   dplyr::filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   dplyr::select(end_year, n_students) } # }

what: wyschooldata: Fetch and Process Wyoming School Data — wyschooldata-package
title: wyschooldata: Fetch and Process Wyoming School Data — wyschooldata-package
text: Downloads processes school data Wyoming Department Education (WDE). Provides functions fetching enrollment data transforming tidy format analysis. Supports data 2002 present.

title: wyschooldata: Fetch and Process Wyoming School Data — wyschooldata-package
text: fetch_enr Fetch enrollment data school year fetch_enr_multi Fetch enrollment data multiple years tidy_enr Transform wide data tidy (long) format id_enr_aggs Add aggregation level flags enr_grade_aggs Create grade-level aggregations get_available_years List available data years

title: wyschooldata: Fetch and Process Wyoming School Data — wyschooldata-package
text: cache_status View cached data files clear_cache Remove cached data files

title: wyschooldata: Fetch and Process Wyoming School Data — wyschooldata-package
text: Wyoming uses 7-digit ID system: District IDs: 7 digits (e.g., 1902000 = Laramie County SD #1) School IDs: 7 digits (unique per school)

title: wyschooldata: Fetch and Process Wyoming School Data — wyschooldata-package
text: Data sourced Wyoming Department Education: WDE Data Portal: https://edu.wyoming.gov/data/ Enrollment Reports: https://edu.wyoming.gov/data/school-district-enrollment--staffing-data/ Reporting System: https://reporting.edu.wyo.gov/

title: wyschooldata: Fetch and Process Wyoming School Data — wyschooldata-package
text: Wyoming enrollment data comes two format eras: PDF Era (2002-2007) Historical PDF files edu.wyoming.gov Modern Era (2008-present) Interactive reports reporting.edu.wyo.gov

title: wyschooldata: Fetch and Process Wyoming School Data — wyschooldata-package
text: Maintainer: Andrew Martin almartin@gmail.com
